Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hey, boy!  What you doin' with my mama's car?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Wait there!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Ain't you ashamed?  Tryin' to steal an old lady's automobile.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I been thinkin' about buyin' me one.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Bull.  You ain't got money for dinner, let alone buy no car.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Now I got enough money for cokes, and since it don't look like you're gonna invite me inside--

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You'd steal the dining room table if I did.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Come to town with me, then.  How'd that be?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Goin' to work anyway.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Goin' to work, huh?  What do you do?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: None of your business.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: No...A lady mechanic?...No...A maid?--

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What do you think I am?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: A waitress.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What line of work are you in?  When you're not stealin' cars?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I tell you, I'm lookin' for suitable employment right at the moment.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What did you do before?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I was in State Prison.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: State Prison?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Guess some little old lady wasn't so nice.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: It was armed robbery.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: My, my, the things that turn up in the driveway these days.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What do y'all do for a good time around here, listen to the grass grow?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Guess you had a lot more fun up at State Prison, huh?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I chopped two toes off of it.  With an axe.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What?  Why?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: To get off the damn work detail, that's why.  Want to see?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I surely don't intend to stand here and look at your dirty feet in the middle of Main Street.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Boy, did you really do that?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You must be crazy.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What's it like?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Prison?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: No, armed robbery.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: It's...I don't know...it isn't like anything.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hah!  I knew you never robbed bo place, you faker.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Yeah, well you got one all right, I guess...but you wouldn't have the gumption to use it.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You just keep your eyes open.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hey, what's your name, anyway?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Clyde Barrow.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hi, I'm Bonnie Parker.  Please to meet you.  EXT. ROAD.  DAY.  VROOM!  The car zooms off down the road, doing 90.  The fast country breakdown music starts up on the sound track, going just as fast as the car.  EXT. CAR.  DAY.  The car, still speeding, further down the road.  We zoom down and look in the rear window.  CLYDE is driving, we see from behind.  BONNIE is all over him, biting his ear, ruffling his hair, running her hands all over him--in short, making passionate love to him while he drives.  The thrill of the robbery and the escape has turned her on sexually.  EXT. CAR.  ANOTHER ANGLE.  DAY.  The camera pulls back and above the car.  The car starts to go crazy in a comical fashion, manifesting to the audience just what is happening to the driver controlling it.  The car swerves all over the road.  The car comes to a sudden halt.  The car starts again.  It swerves this time almost right off the road before it straightens out.  It jumps and jerks.  Another car comes down the road the other way and CLYDE's car swerves so much as to make the other guy drive right off the road into the dirt.  It is almost Mack Sennett stuff, but not quite that much.  INT. CAR.  BONNIE AND CLYDE.  DAY.  BONNIE grabs the wheel and turns it sharply.  EXT. CAR.  DAY.  It hairpins off the road onto a shoulder beneath some trees.  INT. CAR.  BONNIE AND CLYDE.  DAY.  --still settling to a stop.  BONNIE and CLYDE appear to be necking heavily now, punctuated by BONNIE's squeals of passion as she squirms and hops about like a flea, trying to get to CLYDE.  The floor gear-shift is keeping their bodies apart, however.  In exasperation, BONNIE takes the gear shift and shoves it forward out of their way.  She plunges onto CLYDE, burying him from view.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: ...You ready?...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: ...Hey, wait...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Aren't you ready?  Well, get ready!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: C'mon, honey, c'mon, boy...let's go...let's...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I said, cut it out!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Boy...boy...boy...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Boy, what?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Your advertising is dandy.  Folks'd just never guess you don't have a thing to sell.  You better take me home, now.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Wait!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Don't touch me!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: If all you want's stud service, then get on back to West Dallas and stay there the rest of your life!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: But you're worth more'n that, a lot more, and you know it, and that's why you come along with me.  You could find a lover boy on every corner in town and it doesn't make a damn to them whether you're waiting on tables or picking cotton, so long as you cooperate. But it does make a damn to me!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Why?  Because you're different! You're like me and you want different things.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You and me travelin' together, we could cut clean acrost this state, and Kansas, too, and maybe dip into Oklahoma, and Missouri or whatnot, and catch ourselves highpockets and a highheeled ol' time.  We can be somethin' we could never be alone. I'll show you...when we walk into the Adolphus Hotel in San Antone', you wearin' a silk dress, they'll be waitin' on you and believe me, sugar, they're gonna know your last name.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: When'd you figure that all out?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: First time I saw you.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: How come?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: 'Cause you may be the best damn girl in Texas.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Who are you, anyway?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I'll tell you about you.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Lessee...You were born somewheres around East Texas...got a big old family, right?...You went to school, of course, but you didn't take to it much 'cause you was a lot smarter than everybody else anyway.  So you just quit.  Now...  ...When you were sixteen...no, seventeen, there was a guy who worked in...uh...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Cement plant--

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Right.  Cement plant.  And you liked him 'cause he thought you was just as nice as you could be.  You almost married that guy, but then...you thought, no, you didn't think you would.  So you got your job in the cafe...  And every morning you wake up and you hate it.  You just hate it. And you get down there and you put on your white uniform--

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Pink.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: And the truck drivers come in to eat greasy burgers and they kid you and you kid them back, but they're stupid and dumb, boys with big tattoos all over 'em, and you don't like it...And they ask you for dates and sometimes you go...but you mostly don't, and all they ever try is to get into your pants whether you want to or not...and you go home and sit in your room and think, when and how will I ever get away from this?...And now you know.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Change that.  I don't like it.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: God, you're a knockout.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hey, that ain't ours.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Sure it is.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: But we came in this one.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Don't mean we have to go home in it.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Clyde...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Clyde...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, lady.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Where you been keeping yourself?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Slept out by the car.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh...These accommodations ain't particularly deluxe.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: No...If they're after us, I want the first shot.  Come on, you got some work to do.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You're good.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: The best.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: And modest...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Come on.  Got you all set up over here.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Set her spinnin'.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Again.  Come down slow with it...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Ain't you something?  I tell you I'm going to get you a Smith and Wesson, it'll be easier in your hand.  Now try it again once...

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Heighdo.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: No sir...no sir.  You all go right ahead.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Used to be my place.  Not any more. Bank took it.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Yessir, moved us off.  Now it belongs to them.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Well, that's a pitiful shame.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: You're damned right, ma'm.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Me and him put in the years here. Yessir.  So you all go right ahead. We just come by for a last look.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: You all mind?

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Hey, Davis!  Come on over here.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Much obliged.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Otis Harrison.  And this here's Davis.  We worked this place.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Miss Bonnie Parker.  And I'm Clyde Barrow.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: We rob banks.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You just stay in the car and watch and be ready.  You just be ready if I need you.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Scared?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What are you thinkin' about?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Nothin'.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What are you waitin' for?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: This is a stickup.  Just take it easy and nothin' will happen to you. Gimme the money.

Speaker: teller
Dialogue: Heighdy.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Gimme the money!

Speaker: teller
Dialogue: What money?  There ain't no money here, mister.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What do you mean there ain't no money?  This here is a bank, ain't it?

Speaker: teller
Dialogue: This was a bank.  We failed three weeks ago.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What?  What??

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Tell her!  Tell her!

Speaker: teller
Dialogue: As I was tellin' this gentleman, our bank failed last month and ain't no money in it.  I sure am sorry.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Keep it running.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Give me a loaf of bread, a dozen eggs and a quart of milk.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: This is a stickup.  I'll take all the money in that drawer now.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Get the hell out of here!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Damn him, that big son of a bitch... He tried to kill me... I ain't got eyes in back of my head... I didn't want to hurt him.  It wasn't a real robbery... Some food and a little bit of dough.  I'm not against him. Damn!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What was wrong, anyway?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You just blowed it away.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Well...I'm not sure...  Say, them little red things there stickin' up?  Are they gas pumps?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Isn't that interesting?  How does that there gasoline get in my little old car?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: My, you're a smart fellow.  You sure know a lot about automobiles, don't you?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Well, would you know what kind of a car this is?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: No, no.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: No, this is a stolen Chevrolet 8- cylinder coupe.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You a good driver, boy?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: No, I don't think so.  He's better off here...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What's your name, boy?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What's the C.W. for?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I'm Miss Bonnie Parker and this is Mr. Clyde Barrow.   We... rob... banks.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Ain't nothing wrong with that, is there, boy?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: No, he ain't the one.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Unless, Boy, you think you got enough guts for our line of work?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh, a man with a record!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Now look here, I know you got the nerve to short-change old ladies who come in for gas, but what I'm askin' you is have you got what it takes to pull bank jobs with us?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Mr. C.W. Moss?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Prove it.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: C.W., what are you doing?  Why do you do that?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: It's just disgusting, that's why.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: But...but it makes everything sweet!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Clyde, why does he have to stay in the same room as us?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Lemme show you about tomorrow.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Now C.W.'ll be waitin' right outside in the car.  Here is the teller's cage.  Four of them and over here the desks and what have you...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Why, Clyde...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hmmm??

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: In the same room with us?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hell, where else?  Ain't gonna spread out all over the state...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Not yet, anyway.  Now, the door to the bank is here now.  You cover me from there.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Just that I love you so much.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You're the best damn girl in Texas.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: The layout for tomorrow up in Mineola.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: So what?  We take U.S. 85 to Willis Point, don't you know, and cut over on State Highway 28 at Kaufman, keep on goin' till we hit the farm- to-market road that connects to 105 and that's right up by Mineola.  On a Saturday afternoon...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Keep it running.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: This is a stickup.

Speaker: teller
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: This is a stickup.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Let's go!  Let's go!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Come on!  Get it out!

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Stop!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Boy, you gotta be poor in the head. You...!  Count of you I killed a man.  Murder...you too.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Dumb ass stupid.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Ever do a dumb thing like that again, I'll kill you boy!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Ssshh!  If you boys want to talk why don't you go outside?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What do you think of me, C.W.?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Why'nt you come get it?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Whyn't you come get it, C.W.?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: All right, I'll bring it myself.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You simpleton, what would you do if we just pulled out some night while you was asleep?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: That's right, C.W.  We'll always be around to take care of you.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie, I want to talk to you.  Sit down.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Look, I can't get out, but right now you still can.  You say the word and I'll put you on the bus to go back to your Mother.  'Cause you mean a lot to me, honey, and I ain't going to make you run with me. So if you want, you say the word.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Why?  We ain't gonna have a minute's peace.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh, pshaw.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie, we could get killed.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Who'd wanna kill a sweet young thing like me?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I ain't no sweet young thing.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh, Clyde, I can't picture you with a halo, and if you went to the other place you'd rob the Devil blind, so he'd kick you right back to me.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: "What a beautiful thought I am thinking Concernin' that great speckled bird, Remember his name is recorded on the pages of God's Holy word..."

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: All right, now you did foolish things as a young man, honey-love, but you went and paid your debt to society and that was right.  But now you just gettin' back in with the criminal element.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Criminal element!  This is my brother, darlin'.  Shoot, he ain't no more criminal than you are, Blanche.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Well, that ain't what I heard.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Now word of mouth just don't go, darlin', you gotta have the facts. Shoot.  Why he and me growed up together, slept and worked side by side.  God, what a boy he was!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: He's a crook.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Buck!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Clyde!  You son of a bitch!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: How's ma?  How's sister?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Just fine, just fine.  Send their best to you.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, you're fillin' out there. Must be that prison food.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hell no!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Howdy-do.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Howdy-do.  It's real nice to know you.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: I'd like you to meet my wife, Blanche.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Hello.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Everybody, this is C.W. Moss. C.W., my brother Buck and his wife, Blanche.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hey, lemme get the Kodak!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, C.W., go put your pants on. We're gonna take some pictures.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Y'all hear about the guy who thought Western Union was a cowboy's underwear?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Lemme get one of my bride and my brother.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Buck!  Don't take my picture now. I'm just a mess from driving all day.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Oh honey, now you look real fine.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Did you take my picture?  Oh Buck! I declare--

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, Buck, get one of this.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Clyde, you do one of me and my missus.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Let me take on of Bonnie.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hey, brother, let's you and me do a little talkin'.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Here, C.W., take the girls' picture.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: It was you or him, wasn't it?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: That guy you killed.  You had to, didn't ya?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Yeah, he put me in a spot, so I had to.  He didn't have a Chinaman's chance.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: But you had to--

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Yeah.  I had to.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Don't say nothin' to Blanche about it.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, that time you broke out of jail, she talk you into goin' back?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Yeah, you hear about that?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I won't say nothin' to Bonnie about it.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: I appreciate it.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Yeah...say, what d'ya think of Bonnie?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: She's a real peach.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Boy, are we gonna have us a good time!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: We surely are!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Yessir!  What are we gonna do?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well, how's this--I thought we'd all go to Missouri.  They ain't lookin' for me there.  We'll hole up someplace and have us a regular vacation.  All right?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: No trouble, now?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: No trouble.  I ain't lookin' to go back to prison.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hey, what's this I hear about you cuttin' up your toes, boy?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: That ain't but half of it.  I did it so I could get off work detail-- breakin' those damned rocks with a hammer day and night.  Sure enough, next week I got paroled.  I walked out of that god-forsaken jail on crutches.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Shoot--

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Ain't life grand?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: And the doc, he takes him aside, says, "Son, your old mama just gettin' weak and sickly layin' there.  I want you to persuade her to take a little Brandy, y'know, to pick her spirits up." "Why, doc," he says, "you know my mamma is a teetotaler.  She wouldn't touch a drop." "Well, I tell you what," the doc says, "why don't you bring her a fresh quart of milk every day from your farm, 'cept you fix it up so half of it's Brandy and don't let on!" So he does that, doctors it up with Brandy, and his mamma drinks some of it.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: I give him a month's rent in advance.  We're all set.  Let's get inside.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Pull up and unload the stuff.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Honey-love, I'm taking you into our first home.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh look, it's so clean, Buck.  And a Frigidaire...not an icebox!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: He give me the grocery number.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Lemme see, eh 4337...Operator... please ma'm, may I have 4337...if you please?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh...they got linoleum on the counter.  Ain't that clever!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hello, Smitty's grocery...I'd like to order a mess of groceries.  Oh yeah...eh 143 Hillsdale Street. Lessee, about 8 pounds of porkchops, 4 pounds of red beans...a can of Chase and Sandborn...uh.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, isn't this something, Daddy!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Sshh.  Uh...quart of milk...uh 8 bottles of Dr. Pepper and that's it, I guess.  No...no.  Uh...a box of Rice Krispies...Bye now.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Boy, you ain't never gonna beat me but you keep tryin' now.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Jest like an ol' man.  Plays checkers all the time and doesn't pay any attention to his poor lonely wife.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Cut it out now, honey.  I'm gonna teach this boy a lesson he'll never forget.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh mercy me, oh my stars!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh, Daddy!  Yore such a slowpoke!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hush up a little.  They're in the next room.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Shoot, there's always somebody in this room, the next room and ever' other kind of room.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Oof!...now that ain't no nice way to talk about my brother.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I ain't talking about your brother.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Honey, do you ever just want to be alone with Me?  I don't just mean like that...I mean do you ever have the notion of us bein' out together and alone, like at some fancy ball, or, I don't know, where we walk in all dressed and they announce us and it's fancy and in public, but we're alone somehow.  We're separate from everybody else, and they know it.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I always feel like we're separate from everybody else.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Do you, baby?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Quiet!  I'll get it.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Groceries, M'am.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: Six dollars and forty-three cents.

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: Here, M'am, them bags is heavy. Let me carry 'em up for you.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: No thanks, I'll take 'em.

Speaker: buck's voice
Dialogue: What was it?

Speaker: clyde's voice
Dialogue: Quiet.  Open the door.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: C'mon, c'mon...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: "We each of us have a good alibi For being down here in the 'joint'; But few of them really are justified If you get right down to the point. You've heard of a woman's glory Being spent on a downright cur'."

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You want to hear this or not?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: "Still you can't always judge the story As true, being told by her. Now 'Sal' was a gal of rare beauty, Though her features were coarse and tough--"

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Yeah, I knew her.  She was cockeyed and had a hare-lip and no teeth!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: "Now 'Sal' was a gal of rare beauty, Though her features were coarse and tough; She never once faltered from duty To play on the 'up and up'."

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: "Sal told me this tale on the evening Before she was turned out free, And I'll do my best to relate it Just as she told it to me--"

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: It's the law.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Dammit, you almost got us killed!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: What did I do wrong?  I s'pose you'd be happier if I got shot.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Yeah, it would of saved us all a lot of trouble.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Buck, don't let that woman talk to me like that!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: It was a dumb thing to do.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Please, Buck, I didn't marry you to see you shot up!  Please, let's go! Let's get out of here and leave. Make him stop the car and let us out!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Can't.  I killed a man.  We're in this now.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Please!  Please!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Shut up!  Just shut up your big mouth!  At least do that, will ya, just shut up.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Cut it out, Bonnie.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Stop the car.  I want to talk to you.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Get rid of her.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Can't do that.  She's Buck's wife.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Get rid of both of them then.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Why?  What's the matter with you anyway?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: She's what's the matter with me, a damn stupid back country hick without a brain in her head.  She ain't nothin' but prunes and proverbs.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What makes you any better?  What makes you so damn special?  You're just a West Dallas waitress who spent half your time pickin' up truck drivers!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Only special thing about you is your peculiar ideas about lovemakin'--which is no love makin' at all.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Look, Bonnie--

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Clyde...honey...I didn't mean all that, honey.  Blame it on all that shootin', I just felt so bad...sure enough...Clyde?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Okay...Okay, hon...let's get movin'...

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hey, y'all, listen to this here: Law enforcement officers throughout the Southwest are frankly amazed at the way in which will-of-the-wisp bandit Clyde Barrow and his yellow- haired companion, Bonnie Parker, continue to elude their would-be captors.  Since engaging the police in a gun battle on the streets of Joplin Missouri and slaying three of their number...

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, Lord...

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: ...the Barrow gang has been reported as far West as White City, New Mexico, and as far north as Chicago. They have been credited with robbing the Mesquite Bank in the aforementioned White City, the J.J. Landry Oil Refinery in Arp, Texas, the Sanger City National Bank in Denton, Texas on three different occasions.  In addition to these robberies, the fast travelling Barrows have been rumored to have had a hand in the robbing of two Piggly Wiggly stores in Texas, and one A&P store in Missouri, though Chief Percy Hammond, who first identified Clyde Barrow's brother, Buck, as a member of the gang, expressed some doubt that these last robberies were committed by the Barrow Gang alone.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Go on.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hey now, here's something!  Listen here: Lone Cop Arrests Two Officers In Hunt For Barrow.  Police Officer Howard Anderson's heart turned faster than his motorcycle when he forced to the side of the road a roaring black V-8 sedan in which were three men and a blondheaded woman yesterday afternoon.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: When he saw several machine guns in the car he was certain he'd caught Clyde Barrow, Bonnie Parker, and maybe Buck Barrow and the third unidentified member of the gang. It took a lot of telephoning and explaining to convince the motorcycle cop that his captives were two highway patrolmen and a blonde-haired stenographer from the Highway Patrol--.  Haw!  Haw!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Anderson was held up as an example for every other Texas peace officer today. "That was a mighty brave thing," explained Highway Patrol Chief L.C. Winston.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Sheriff!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Sweet Jesus, I never seen shootin' like that!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well, now, getta load of this.  I want y'all to know we are in the custody of Cap'n Frank Bryce, and Frank here is a Texas Ranger.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Say there, peacemaker.  I believe you got your spurs all tangled up. You're in Missouri, you know that?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You didn't know you was in Missouri?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Didn't you?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: --Now you ain't hardly doin' your job, Texas Ranger.  You oughta be home lookin' after the rights of poor folks, not out chasin' after us.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Easy there, Clyde.  Why take is so personal.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Reg'lar laws is one thing.  But this here bounty hunting, we got to discourage that.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Like how, Clyde?--

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: --uh-uh.  Take his picture.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: --and all bein' just as friendly as pie.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: ...yeah, yeah...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: --why we 'bout the friendliest folks in the world.  Texas Ranger waves his big ol' gun at us, and we just welcome him like he's one of our own.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Buck, get the Kodak!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hot dog!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: We're mighty proud to have a Texas Ranger in the family.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: ...keep him set on the hood, there...more to the sun, like that...yeah...when all his ranger friends see this...I bet he's gonna wish he was dead!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: --don't make sense, do it?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: C'mon, now, Clyde, you and Bonnie first.  Move into him, right close, right friendly.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: All righty  Don't move, now, hear?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: How's this? "Captain Bryce and new found friend."

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: ...yeah, yeah...quick, Buck, get it...

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: ...I'm gettin' it, I'm gettin' it.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: I got the picture.  I got the picture...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Lemme be, lemme be...

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: I got the PICTURE!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: ...All right, all right...  WE GOT YOU...HEAR?... REMEMBER... YOU... YOUR FACE...WE GOT IT...WE GOT YOU...WE GOT YOU...WE GOT YOU...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: This is the Barrow gang.  Everybody just take it easy and nobody will get hurt.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Don't do nothin' silly now.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: That your money or the bank's?

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Mine.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Keep it, then.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Next time I'll aim a little lower.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Get a good look at us!  We're the Barrow boys.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Happy birthday.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Kick it in the pants, C.W.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: We got to make that state line!

Speaker: bank guard
Dialogue: Then he saw me goin' for my gun. Clyde Barrow himself, I mean.  And suddenly I was starin' into the face of death!

Speaker: woman teller
Dialogue: Tsk, tsk.

Speaker: photographer
Dialogue: Just look this way, Mr. Hawkins.

Speaker: first policeman
Dialogue: Step on it, Randolph.  We gotta catch 'em 'fore they reach the state line!

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: Clyde?...he looked like, well he looked real...clean...and Bonnie, she's too much a lady ever to be caught with a cigar in her mouth...I don't care what you heard before. I saw 'em right here, not twenty minutes ago...  --and all's I can say is, they did right by me, and I'm bringin' me a mess of flowers to their funeral.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Okay, relax.  We're in Oklahoma now. Slow down.

Speaker: first policeman
Dialogue: Turn around.  Don't waste no more gas.

Speaker: second policeman
Dialogue: Ain't we gone to catch 'em?

Speaker: first policeman
Dialogue: Hell, they're over the State line. That's out of our jurisdiction.

Speaker: second policeman
Dialogue: Why don't we get 'em anyway?

Speaker: first policeman
Dialogue: I ain't gone to risk my life in Oklahoma.  That's their problem.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hell.  That ain't much, is it?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Times is hard,

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well, let's get to it.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: This is Clyde Barrow.  Clyde, Buck...Bonnie...C.W. Clyde, Clyde again...Buck...Bonnie...C.W.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie...C.S....Clyde...

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Um...eh...Clyde?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hah?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Uh, Clyde...well...what about Blanche?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: WHAT?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Well, why not?  Say I earned my share!  Same as everybody.  I coulda got killed same as everybody, and I'm wanted by the law same as everybody.  Besides I coulda got snake bit sleepin' in them woods every night!  I'm just a nervous wreck and that's the truth.  And I have to listen to sass from Miss Bonnie Parker all the time.  I deserve mine!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Okay...okay...hold your horses, Blanche.  You'll get your share.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Married a preacher's daughter and she still thinks she's takin' the collection.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Well, don't spend it all in one place now, hear?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: She'll be doin' right well to spend it at all.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Look, Bonnie, I've said it and I guess I'll keep sayin' it before we're thru--Blanche is Buck's wife and Buck is family.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: --she's such a silly-Billy...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: My family could use some of that money.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Them laws have been hangin' round your mamas house 'til all hours, Bonnie.  It's just too risky to go there.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Well, where can we go?  We rob the damn banks, what else do we do?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I hear you, C.W.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Oh, now...now, dear...

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Mmmm...sweet thing...

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Say, isn't that your car, Eugene?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: That's my car!  Hey!

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: I'll tear 'em apart!  Those punks! Steal a man's car right out from under him!  Wait till I get my hands on those kids, Velma, I'll show 'em!

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: What if they have guns, Eugene?

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: We'd better get the police and let them handle this.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Turn around and let's get back to town.  We'll go get the sheriff.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: They stopped chasin' us.  They turned around.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Let's take 'em.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Oh, my Lord, they're comin' after us.

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Step on it, Velma, step on it!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: C'mon, get out!  Get out of there, I said.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Get in here.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: I'm Eugene Grizzard.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: I'm Velma Davis.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Well, howdy!  We're the Barrow gang. That there is Clyde drivin' and I'm Buck.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Look, don't be scared, folks.  It ain't like you was the law.  You're just folks like us.

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, that's the truth.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I expect you been readin' about us.

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Yes, Velma, we have too.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Well, you two must be in love, I bet.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Well, when you gonna marry the girl, boy?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: So then she drinks her milk down again, every drop.  And she looks over at her son and says, "Son, whatever you do, don't sell that cow!"

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: How old are you, honey?

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Thirty-three.

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Now I ordered some French fries, didn't I?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Yeah, here you go.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Take it easy on those French fries, Velma.  Ain't that right, Eugene?

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: This isn't mine.  I ordered mine well done.  Who's got the other hamburger?

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: That's okay, forget it.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Haw!  I sure am havin' a good time! How 'bout you folks?  Ain't you glad we picked you up?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, maybe y'all ought to join up with us.

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Ha!  Wouldn't they be surprised back home to hear that?

Speaker: velma
Dialogue: Yeah.  What would Martha and Bill say if they heard that?

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: Lordy!  They'd throw a fit!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What do you do, anyway?

Speaker: eugene
Dialogue: I'm an undertaker.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Get them out of here.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: ...see anythin', Buck?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: --not yet, boy.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: ...Well, where do you think she could've gone?...Buck?...Buck?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Jesus, I don't know...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: There!  There!  There!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Leave me alone!  Leave me alone!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: ...Hey, hey now...just where did you think you were goin'?...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: --Huh.  Bonnie?  Where?  Where?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I don't know!  You're hurting me, I was just scared is all...and my mama's been on my mind, and she's gettin' so old...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Boy, don't ever leave without sayin' somethin'.  You really scared me, Bonnie.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: But I mean it, though.  I want to see my mama.  Please, Clyde.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Okay, sweetheart.

Speaker: sister
Dialogue: Here you are, we been cuttin' and pastin' everything we could find about you in the papers.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Hey look, here's that one I took of you, Clyde.  That came out just fine!

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Oh, Horsey! keep your tail up, keep yer tail up, keep yer tail up, Oh, Horsey! keep yer tail up, Why don't you make it rise.

Speaker: bonnie's uncle
Dialogue: Where y'all headed from here?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I don't know, what y'all got in mind?  At this point we ain't headin' to anywhere, we're just runnin' from.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Don't go yet, Mama.

Speaker: uncle's voice
Dialogue: C'mere, c'mere you little corn roller.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: ...you know, Clyde, I read about y'all in the papers and I'm jes' scared.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Sugar, make mama stay a while yet.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Now Mrs. Parker, don't y'all believe what you read in the papers! That's the law talking there.  They want us to look big so's they'll look big when they catch us.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: --and they can't do that.  Why, I'm even better at runnin' than robbin' banks--aw shoot, if we done half the stuff they said we did, we'd be millionaires, wouldn't we, old sugar.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: ...Maybe you know the way with her, then.  I'm just an old woman and I don't know nothin...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: We'll be quittin' this just as soon as the hard times is over, Mother Parker, I can tell you that.  Why me and Bonnie were just talkin' the other day and we talked about when we'd settle down and get us a home, and Bonnie said, "I couldn't bear to live morn'n three miles from my precious mother." Now how'd you like that, Mother Parker?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Don't believe I would.  I surely don't.  Bye, baby.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: How long have ya had it?

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Touch it, honey!  Go on!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, no, Daddy!  No!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What are you all doin'?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Well, why don't you all go play with it somewhere else?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: What's bothering her?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Not now, Blanche.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: What's bothering her, Clyde?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I said go somewhere else!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie's hungry, C.W. I saw a chicken place a few miles back. Who all wants to go get some food?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I sure do.  I'm plenty tired of sittin' around here anyway.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: You can't drive, honeylove.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Just five chicken dinners, and get somethin' for dessert.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: See if they got peach ice cream.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I hate you all.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I hate y'all, too.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: no, I really hate you.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh, baby, I've got the blues so bad...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie?...is it your mama, what your mama said?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What mama?...she's just an old woman now...I have no mama...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: ...so funny...I thought when we first went out, we were really goin' somewhere...but this is it-- we're just goin', huh?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Do you care about where we're goin'?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Not as long as you care about me.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Why I love you, sugar.

Speaker: bonnie's voice
Dialogue: --enough to die with me, baby?... 'cause I think that's where we're goin'...I surely do.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: --wherever.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: So what?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, God...

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, if I could!  If I could just do that one thing!  Oh, there's no tellin' why this all happened.  I was a preacher's daughter.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Baptist...oh, and he thought the world of Buck, my daddy did, even knowing that Buck was serving time in jail.  He forgave him for that 'cause he paid his debt to society.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Hey, C.W., I ain't got my money. Give me some, will you?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Get Sheriff Smoot on the phone.

Speaker: bonnie's voice
Dialogue: Ready?

Speaker: clyde's voice
Dialogue: Aw Bonnie--

Speaker: bonnie's voice
Dialogue: C'mon!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Lie down now, honey.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I've done enough!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You have to lie down...it's the only way we can tell what we'll look kike together.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Whatta you think?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: That's not the right tie!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You can't wear polka-dots on an occasion like this.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well what--

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Stripes.  Don't go away now.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Perfect.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: OK, o.k.  If we're gonna do this, at least I can tie it myself.  Lie down before you fall down.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Better?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Much.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: All right, shut your eyes now.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: No, you first.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: One for the money.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Two for the show.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Three to get ready--

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: The men are on the other side.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Oh, God, please help us!  Dear Father in Heaven, get us out of this and Buck will never do another bad thing in his life!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: My eyes!  ...light hurts so bad...

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Please, please get us to a doctor! Tell Clyde to get us to a doctor. We'll die here.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: --here, hon'.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Clyde, Clyde, please get us to a doctor.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: He's your brother!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Buck can't be moved, now, hon'.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: Clyde?...Clyde?...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Right here, boy.

Speaker: buck
Dialogue: I believe I lost my shoes...maybe the dog hid 'em...

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Surrender!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Don't kill him!  Don't kill him! He's dying!

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: Don't die, Daddy.  Don't die!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Saw...saw a farm...up ahead...gotta get...a car...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Baby, no...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Shhh!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Oh, no.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I can't die without Clyde.  I just can't.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Head out, C.W.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Who are you, boy?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: It's Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Who was they, Pa?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: That was Bonnie and Clyde, the bank robbers.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Who's there?  Who is it?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Clarence!

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: God, it's good to see you, boy!

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: What's that on your chest?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Jesus, what happened to them?  You in trouble, son?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Why'd you get yourself marked up? A tattoo!  What in hell made you do a damn fool thing like that?

Speaker: billy
Dialogue: I was in the bunch that took 'er. See here?  Can you make me out? Here I am, see here, right behind Joe Boyd here.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Sure enough, Billy, is that your head there?

Speaker: billy
Dialogue: Still can't figure how we let them other two get away.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Yeah, seems as how nobody can get 'em somehow.

Speaker: billy
Dialogue: Yeah...well, maybe this boy'll be the one to do it, this Hamer guy. Boy if he can't do it, Sheriff, ain't nobody but the whole U.S. Army can do it.

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: You hear he quit the Rangers on account of Texas got that woman governor.  Said he wouldn't work under no woman.

Speaker: billy
Dialogue: Yeah, that's somethin' all right. Say, how many they say he shot anyway in his day?

Speaker: pete
Dialogue: Sixty-five they say.

Speaker: billy
Dialogue: Son of a sea-cook!

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: Excuse me, am I in the right place? Is this Sheriff Smoot?

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: Hamer.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: He was shot in too many pieces to pick off the ground!  Fled...what do they know, the papers or the police?...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Why, while we were all lyin' around here, near dead, they had us holdin' up the Grand Prairie National Bank!  They hung that one on us just for luck, I guess.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Tell you what.  Soon's we get well, we're gonna take that bank!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: They don't know nothin'--do they, sugar?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You did all you could, hon'. Nobody coulda done more.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You can just thank your lucky stars that's all you are.  So long's they don't have your last name, you're home safe.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Mr. Barrow's lookin' out for your interests, boy.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Ain't that somethin' for me?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well now, you been real nice to us, and I tell you what, let us pay you forty dollars for your hospitality, what do you say?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: No, no, no.  I don't want your money.  I'm just pleased to have your company.  Any friend of my boy's...

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: You're welcome here, now you know that.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: You look like trash, boy, marked up like that.  Cheap trash.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Bonnie, what does she know.  She's just cheap trash herself.  Look what they do to you, and you don't even get your name in the paper-- just pictures put on your skin, by "Bonnie and Clyde"--  --why they're a coupla kids.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: I'm just glad your ma ain't alive to see that thing.

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: Blanche Barrow.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: What?  What?  Who is it?

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: You know your husband's dead.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: You're going to prison.

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I know it.

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: Where's the rest of 'em?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: Where's the rest of 'em?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: I just don't know.  I don't know.

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: How'd you get in with them?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: And we run off, God, I was scared. And then it was run all the time, and I wanted to go, I begged to go, but Clyde and Bonnie and C.W.--

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: C.W.  C.W. who?

Speaker: blanche
Dialogue: C.W. Moss.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Want a ginger-snap, Bonnie?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: It's real nice here, just the two of us like this.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Look here, honey, remember this?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Yeah, at the motel.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: You sure don't resemble that no more.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What you writin' this time?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: I'm writing a poem about us.  I'm writing our story.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Oh, are you?  Let's hear it.  If it's good, I'll mail it in to the Law and it'll be printed in all the papers again.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Just let me finish this line.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Okay, here it is.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: "The Story of Bonnie and Clyde"

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: The road gets dimmer and dimmer; Sometimes you can hardly see; But it's fight man to man, And do all you can, For they know they can never be free.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: If they try to act like citizens And rent them a nice little flat About the third night They're invited to fight By a sub-gun's rat-tat-tat.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Damn!  That's me!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: In that poem!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Right in the paper!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Jesse James!  You hear 'bout old Jesse, now you goin' to hear 'bout Clyde!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Pshhhhhh!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Damn, Bonnie!  You musta been one hell of a waitress!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Oooooh, that Clyde!  That's my boy, that Clyde!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie...  The Poem of Bonnie and Clyde!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: The Story.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: The Story of Bonnie and Clyde!  Oh, child, you really did tell that story!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Damn!...damn...damn!

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, listen, Bonnie, how do you feel?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I mean you feel like you're s'posed to feel after you've uh...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Just.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well, that's good, ain't it. Reason I ask is, I uh... Well, I figger it's a good idea to ask.  I mean how else do I tell if I did it the way...

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Hey.  You done just perfect.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I did, didn't I?  I mean I did, I really did.  I did it, I did, I mean this was my first time and it was just like rollin' off a log when it comes right down to it, it was easy, I mean I didn't even have to try...

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Boy, they expect you to go downtown with 'em tomorrow?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Bonnie and Clyde.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: ...better go then, you better go, better go...  --but when they get back in the car to come on home, don't get in with them.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: You just listen to your Pa fer once! Cain't you do that?  I'm yore Daddy, I'm your kin, not Clyde.

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: I made a deal and got you off with a coupla years!

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: And whatever you do, don't let onto them, hear?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: What do you think, Clarence?

Speaker: malcolm
Dialogue: Mebbe.  Just you be off'n the streets of that town when they go to get in their car.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie?  Bonnie, will you marry me?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: How could I do that, Clyde?  You know it's impossible.  We'd have to go to a Justice of the Peace and the Justice of the Peace is a lawman.  We couldn't even take out a license.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey now, you sound like you been givin' it some thought on your own.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie...are you crying, honey?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Clyde, why do you want to marry me?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: To make an honest woman out of you.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Clyde...what would you do, what would you do it some miracle happened and we could walk out tomorrow morning and start all over again, clean, with no record, with nobody after us?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Well...I guess I'd do it all different.  First off, I wouldn't live in the same state where we pull our jobs.  We'd live in one state and stay clean there, and when we wanted to take a bank, we'd go to another state...and...

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Bonnie?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Hey, Bonnie?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: What happened to C.W.?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: He stopped off in that hardware store to get light bulbs for his daddy.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Boy, my feet are sweatin'.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You plannin' to drive with your shoes off?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Sure, why not?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Damn!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You gonna wear 'em?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Sure, drive with one eye shut.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Isn't that the prettiest thing, hon? Just look here, you can see every little fingernail on her hands.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: It is a pretty thing, honey.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: We got any peaches?  I sure could go for a peach right now.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Whyn't we do it tomorrow?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Do what?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Tomorrow's Sunday, ain't it?  We could drive all night and be on that golf course tomorrow morning!

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You sure you feel up to it?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Where is that boy?  He's gone too long.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: You take a bite, hon.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: No, it's takin' too long.  What if something happened?

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: Nothin' happened.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: Go take a look, see what's keepin' him.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: He ain't there.

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: C'mon, let's go.

Speaker: bonnie
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: clyde
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: hamer
Dialogue: Barrow!
